text.0: to splendid agni seated by the altar loving well his home i bring the food as twere his place of birth.
text.1: i clothe the bright one with my hymn as with a robe him with the car of light brighthued dispelling gloom.
text.2: child of a double birth he grasps at triple food in the years course what he hath swallowed grows anew.
text.3: he by anothers mouth and tongue a noble bull with other as an elephant consumes the trees.
text.4: the pair who dwell together moving in the dark bestir themselves both parents hasten to the babe.
text.5: impetuoustongued destroying springing swiftly forth one to be watched and cherished strengthener of his sire.
text.6: for man thou friend of men these steeds of thine are yoked impatient lightly running ploughing blackened lines.
text.7: discordantminded fleet gliding with easy speed urged onward by the wind and rapid in their course.
text.8: dispelling on their way the horror of black gloom making a glorious show these flames of his fly forth.
text.9: when oer the spacious tract he spreads himself abroad and rushes panting on with thunder and with roar.
text.10: amid brown plants he stoops as if adorning them and rushes bellowing like a bull upon his wives.
text.11: proving his might he decks the glory of his form and shakes his horns like one terrific hard to stay.
text.12: now covered now displayed he grasps as one who knows his restingplace in those who know him well.
text.13: a second time they wax and gather godlike power and blending both together change their parents form.
text.14: the maidens with long tresses hold him in embrace dead they rise up again to meet the living one.
text.15: releasing them from age with a loud roar he comes filling them with new spirit living unsubdued.
text.16: licking the mantle of the mother far and wide he wanders over fields with beasts that flee apace.
text.17: strengthening all that walk licking up all around a blackened path forsooth he leaves whereer he goes.
text.18: o agni shine resplendent with our wealthy chiefs like a loudsnorting bull accustomed to the house.
text.19: thou casting off thine infant wrappings blazest forth as though thou hadst put on a coat of mail for war.
text.20: may this our perfect prayer be dearer unto thee than an imperfect prayer although it please thee well.
text.21: with the pure brilliancy that radiates from thy form mayest thou grant to us abundant store of wealth.
text.22: grant to our chariot to our house o agni a boat with moving feet and constant oarage.
text.23: one that may further well our wealthy princes and all the folk and be our certain refuge.
text.24: welcome our laud with thine approval agni may earth and heaven and freely flowing rivers.
text.25: yield us long life and food and corn and cattle and may the red dawns choose for us their choicest.
